member.name: T:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap
member.summary: Encapsulates a binary series of cell status table.
member.remarks:
This type holds a field called , it is the only field provided to be used as the entry to create or update collection. If you want to add elements into it, you can use , or just or :
var cellMap = CellMap.Empty; cellMap += 0; // Adds 'r1c1' into the collection. cellMap.Add(0); // Adds 'r1c2' into the collection. cellMap.AddRange(stackalloc[] { 2, 3, 4 }); // Adds 'r1c345' into the collection. cellMap |= anotherCellMap; // Adds a list of another instance of type 'CellMap' into the current collection.
If you want to learn more information about this type, please visit this wiki page.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap._high
member.summary:
Indicates the internal two values, which represents 81 bits. represent the higher 40 bits and represents the lower 41 bits, where each bit is:
bit (1) The corresponding cell is contained in this collection
bit (0) The corresponding cell is not contained in this collection

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap._low
member.summary:
Indicates the internal two values, which represents 81 bits. represent the higher 40 bits and represents the lower 41 bits, where each bit is:
bit (1) The corresponding cell is contained in this collection
bit (0) The corresponding cell is not contained in this collection

member.summary: Determines whether the current list of cells are all lie in an intersection area, i.e. a locked candidates.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.BlockMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask of block that all cells in this collection spanned.
member.remarks: For example, if the cells are { 0, 1, 27, 28 }, all spanned blocks are 0 and 3, so the return mask is 0b000001001 (i.e. 9).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.RowMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask of row that all cells in this collection spanned.
member.remarks: For example, if the cells are { 0, 1, 27, 28 }, all spanned rows are 0 and 3, so the return mask is 0b000001001 (i.e. 9).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.ColumnMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask of column that all cells in this collection spanned.
member.remarks: For example, if the cells are { 0, 1, 27, 28 }, all spanned columns are 0 and 1, so the return mask is 0b000000011 (i.e. 3).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.CoveredLine
member.summary: Indicates the covered line.
member.remarks: If the covered house can't be found, it'll return .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.Count
member.summary: Indicates the number of the values stored in this collection.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.CoveredHouses
member.summary: Indicates all houses covered. This property is used to check all houses that all cells of this instance covered. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the house index 0 (block 1) and 9 (row 1); however, if cells spanned two houses or more (e.g. cells { 0, 1, 27 }), this property won't contain any houses.
member.remarks: The return value will be an value indicating each houses. Bits set 1 are covered houses.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.Houses
member.summary: All houses that the map spanned. This property is used to check all houses that all cells of this instance spanned. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the house index 0 (block 1), 9 (row 1), 18 (column 1) and 19 (column 2).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.ExpandedPeers
member.summary: Gets the expanded peers of the current map.
member.remarks: An Expanded Peers is a list of cells that contains all peer cells of each cell appeared in the current collection. For example, if a collection contains cells r1c123, this collection will be the result of the expression PeersMap[r1c1] | PeersMap[r1c2] | PeersMap[r1c3], where the member PeersMap corresponds to the array .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.PeerIntersection
member.summary: Indicates the peer intersection of the current instance.
member.remarks: A Peer Intersection is a set of cells that all cells from the base collection can be seen. For more information please visit this link.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.StringChunks

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.CompareTo(Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@)
member.returns:
An indicating the result. The result value only contains 3 possible values: 1, 0 and -1. The comparison rule is:
If holds more cells than , then return 1 indicating is greater.
If holds less cells than , then return -1 indicating is greater.
If They are same length, then checks for indices held:
If holds a cell whose index is greater than all cells appeared in , then return 1 indicating is greater.
If holds a cell whose index is greater than all cells appeared in , then return -1 indicating is greater.
If all rules are compared, but they are still considered equal, then return 0.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.ToString(System.String)
member.remarks:
Supported format strings:
"N" or "n"
Gets the normal representation of the cells, i.e. An RxCy notation. For more information please visit the XML documentation comments of type .
"B" or "b"
Converts the current instance into a binary representation, using bit 0 to indicate a certain cell not containing in the collection; otherwise bit 1.
"B+" or "b+"
Same as format "B" (or "b"), but with whitespace after each 27 bits.
"T" or "t" Converts the current instance into a table representation.
If is or empty string "", the result string will be same as the case that is "N" or "n".

Condition Meaning

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap.op_Modulus(Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@)
member.summary: Expands the operator to (a & b).PeerIntersection & b.
member.param: The template map that the base map to check and cover.

remarks.para: The operator is commonly used for checking eliminations, especially in type 2 of deadly patterns.

For example, if we should check the eliminations of digit d, we may use the expression
(urCells & grid.CandidatesMap[d]).PeerIntersection & grid.CandidatesMap[d]
to express the eliminations are the peer intersection of cells of digit d appeared in urCells. This expression can be simplified to
urCells % grid.CandidatesMap[d]

member.name: T:Sudoku.Concepts.Crosshatch
member.summary: Represents a crosshatch factor. The type can describe an elimination that starts with a certain cell (or some cells), and eliminates candidates in some cells. The concept is commonly used by logical technique "Hidden Single".

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.Crosshatch.CellsGroupMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask that is used for getting and checking the cells in the mask .

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.Crosshatch.PerCellMaxMask
member.summary: Indicates the mask that is used for separating multiple cells in a group.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.Crosshatch.CrosshatchingHousesList
member.summary: Indicates the houses list that represents the possible houses that a crosshatch will be used.

summary.para: Indicates the inner mask.

The mask uses 46 bits to describe two intersections and a digit information. The higher 4 bits is the digit, and last 42 bits are two intersections representing the start and end intersection. For example, r5c5(3) can eliminate r789c5(3) in block 8, then we can construct two intersections to describe r5c5 and r789c5, putting them into the last 42 bits. A single candidate will use 7 bits to describe (for cell indices from 0 to 80, i.e. r1c1 to r9c9).

member.name: F:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid._values
member.summary: Indicates the inner array that stores the masks of the sudoku grid, which stores the in-time sudoku grid inner information.
member.remarks:
The field uses the mask table of length 81 to indicate the status and all possible candidates holding for each cell. Each mask uses a value, but only uses 11 of 16 bits.
16 8 0 |-------|-------| | |--|--------| 16 12 9 0
Here the first-nine bits indicate whether the digit 1-9 is possible candidate in the current cell respectively, and the higher 3 bits indicate the cell status. The possible cell status are:
Status name Description
Empty cell (i.e. ) The cell is currently empty, and wait for being filled.
Modifiable cell (i.e. ) The cell is filled by a digit, but the digit isn't the given by the initial grid.
Given cell (i.e. ) The cell is filled by a digit, which is given by the initial grid and can't be modified.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.#ctor(System.Int32@,Sudoku.Concepts.GridCreatingOption)
member.summary: Creates a instance via the pointer of the first element of the cell digit, and the creating option.

param.name: firstElement
param.para: The reference of the first element.

target.name: in-parameter
target.i: Please note that the parameter is an parameter, which has the same meaning for returns or locals. You can treat it as the first element in an array of elements. Different with parameter, modifier has the same semantic as instead of .

target.name: method
target.i:
C# 7.3 introduces a new keyword as the parameter modifier to make the parameter pass by reference and be read-only. Therefore, this keyword contains 2 usages:
Ensure the argument to be read-only and cannot be modified. Otherwise, a new copied instance will be created to prevent any modifications on the original variable.
Ensure the argument to pass by reference in order to treat it as the pointer or array of elements of this type, and treat the argument as the first element of the whole element series.
From the above meaning on this keyword, we can conclude that we should regard it as parameters, but C# requires us using the keyword as the modifier on a parameter rather than .

member.exception: Throws when the argument is reference.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets the digit that has been filled in the specified cell.
member.param: The cell you want to get or set a value.

value.para: The value you want to set. The value should be between 0 and 8. If assigning -1, that means to re-compute all candidates.

The values set into the grid will be regarded as the modifiable values. If the cell contains a digit, it will be covered when it is a modifiable value. If the cell is a given cell, the setter will do nothing.

member.returns:
The value that the cell filled with. The possible values are:
-1 The status of the specified cell is .
>= 0 and < 9
The actual value that the cell filled with. 0 is for the digit 1, 1 is for the digit 2, etc..
member.exception: Throws when the specified cell keeps a wrong cell status value. For example, .

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.Exists(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current grid contains the digit in the specified cell.
member.returns:
The method will return a ? value (contains three possible cases: , and ). All values corresponding to the cases are below:
The cell is an empty cell and contains the specified digit.
The cell is an empty cell but doesn't contain the specified digit.
The cell is not an empty cell.

remarks.para: Note that the method will return a ?, so you should use the code 'grid.Exists(cell, digit) is true' or 'grid.Exists(cell, digit) == true' to decide whether a condition is true.
In addition, because the type is ? rather than , the result case will be more precisely than the indexer , which is the main difference between this method and that indexer.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.Grid.GetCandidates(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the candidate mask part of the specified cell.
member.param: The cell offset you want to get.

returns.para:
The candidate mask. The return value is a 9-bit value, where each bit will be:
0 The cell doesn't contain the possibility of the digit.
1 The cell contains the possibility of the digit.
For example, if the result mask is 266 (i.e. 0b100_001_010 in binary), the value will indicate the cell contains the digit 2, 4 and 9.

summary.para: Parses a string value and converts to this type.

If you want to parse a PM grid, you should decide the mode to parse. If you use compatible mode to parse, all single values will be treated as given values; otherwise, recommended mode, which uses '<d>' or '*d*' to represent a value be a given or modifiable one. The decision will be indicated and passed by the second parameter .

member.name: F:Sudoku.SolutionWideReadOnlyFields.HouseCells

summary.para:
The map of all cell offsets in its specified house. The indices is between 0 and 26, where:
0..9 Block 1 to 9.
9..18 Row 1 to 9.
18..27 Column 1 to 9.

member.example: 'HouseCells[0]': all cell offsets in the house 0 (block 1).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.WithCandidates

summary.para: Indicates the output should be with candidates. If the output is single line, the candidates will indicate the candidates-have-eliminated before the current grid status; if the output is multi-line, the candidates will indicate the real candidate at the current grid status.

If the output is single line, the output will append the candidates value at the tail of the string in ':candidate list'. In addition, candidates will be represented as 'digit', 'row offset' and 'column offset' in order.

member.returns: The output should be with candidates.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Formatting.GridFormatter.TreatValueAsGiven
member.summary: Indicates the output will treat modifiable values as given ones. If the output is single line, the output will remove all plus marks '+'. If the output is multi-line, the output will use '<digit>' instead of '*digit*'.
member.returns: The output will treat modifiable values as given ones.

member.remarks: This format will use a triplet to describe a cell. If the cell has already been filled with a value, it will be output at the first digit of that triplet. For example, the triplet 900 means the cell is filled with the digit 9. In addition, if the cell is empty, the triplet is always 001.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.Notations.K9Notation
member.summary: Encapsulates a set of methods that handles a variety of instances, using K9 notation to output the representation, or parse a value to convert it to the suitable-typed instance.

remarks.para: The K9 notation is a notation to describe a set of cells that uses letters A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H and K to describe the row, and uses digits 1 to 9 to describe the column. For example, C8 means the cell at row 3 and column 8. The letter I and J aren't used in this notation because they are confusing with digit 1. However, they can also be used in Chinese notations, for example, K8 in traditional notation is same as I8 in Chinese K9 notation rule.
For more information about this concept, please visit this link.
Please note that the type is an type, which means you cannot instantiate any objects. In addition, the type contains a instance constructor, which disallows you deriving any types.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Text.Notations.K9Notation.Letters
member.summary: Indicates all possible letters that used in the row notation.

member.summary: Try to parse the string and convert it into a single cell index.

member.remarks:
Pattern explanation:
Match a character in the set [A-IKa-ik] atomically at least 1 and at most 9 times.
Match a character in the set [1-9] atomically at least 1 and at most 9 times.

member.param: Indicates whether the method should use upper-casing to handle the result notation of cells. For example, if , the concept "row 3 column 3" will be displayed as C3; otherwise, c3.
Indicates whether the method should avoid confusion for the letter I and digit 1. For example, if , row 9 column 9 will be notated as K9; otherwise, I9.
Indicates the separator string value that inserts two coordinate elements, to combine them. For example, cells C1 and D2 can be combined to C1, D2 if the separator is ", ".

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.Notations.RxCyNotation
member.summary: Encapsulates a set of methods that handles a variety of instances, using RxCy notation to output the representation, or parse a value to convert it to the suitable-typed instance.

remarks.para: The RxCy notation is a notation to describe a set of cells that uses letter R (or its lower case r) to describe a row label, and uses the other letter C (or its lower case c) to describe a column label. For example, R4C2 means the cell at row 4 and column 2.
For more information about this concept, please visit this link.
Please note that the type is an type, which means you cannot instantiate any objects. In addition, the type contains a instance constructor, which disallows you deriving any types.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.Parsing.GridParsingOption
member.summary: Represents a grid parsing type.

summary.para: Indicates the susser format, which means all grid values will be displayed in one line with empty cell character '0' or '.'.

Indicates the shorten susser format, which means all grid values will be displayed in one line with empty cell character '0' or '.'. Different with the option , this option will continue shortening the code. The option will omit the continuous empty cells to a * in a single line. For example, the code
080630040200085009090000081000300800000020000006001000970000030400850007010094050
will be displayed as
08063*40,2*85009,09*81,*300800,*2*,006001*,97*30,40085*7,01*94050
via this option. We use the colon , to separate each line of 9 numbers, and then omit the most continuous empty cells to a *.
Indicates the pencil marked grid (PM grid), which means all grid candidates will be displayed using a table.
Indicates the table format, which means all grid values will be displayed using a table with empty cell character '0' or '.'.
Sudoku explainer format (9 characters in a row, and 9 rows).
Sukaku sudoku format (only contains the digits and the whitespace).
Sukaku single line format, which uses '0' to be a placeholder.
Excel sudoku format (only contains the digits and the tab character).
Open sudoku format.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Parsing.Utf8GridParser.CompatibleFirst
member.summary: Indicates whether the parser will change the execution order of PM grid. If the value is , the parser will check compatible one first, and then check recommended parsing plan ('<d>' and '*d*').

member.name: P:Sudoku.Text.Parsing.Utf8GridParser.ShortenSusserFormat
member.summary: Indicates whether the parser will use shorten mode to parse a susser format grid. If the value is , the parser will omit the continuous empty notation .s or 0s to a *.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Text.ResourceTextFormatterAttribute
member.summary:
Marks on a method to tell the user the method is only used for the formatting. This attribute implies two things:
The name of the method is appeared in resource dictionary
The method can only be invoked by reflection.
